This video doesn’t actually make it better. But the comment section does. There are thousands of people with death anxiety. Starting from like 10 maybe to even 70-80 I guess. The thing that makes us feel better is the fact that ALL OF US fear death, but not all of us are READY to speak up about it. It is a tough, scary, anxious, unknown, mysterious and terrifying topic to discuss, but still, some of us share their experiences of death here. Knowing that I am not alone makes me feel better. It sounds awful, but it’s true. This is what makes life pretty and precious.
We don’t know if there’s a God or Goddess or many Gods that created universe, us etc. We don’t know if there’s some Higher Powers. We don’t know if there’s energy. We don’t know anything. And if there’s nothing at the end and we’re just gonna sleep forever….maybe….that’s for better? Maybe we’re created like that for the better? The best theory is reincarnation. It would be amazing, cause it’s not boring. I guess if there’s heaven and hell we’ll just get bored if we’ll forever spend our time there. So maybe “nothing” is not that bad.
Ofc, I’m just trying to convince myself, but maybe…it’s really not that bad🤔
The one thing I really understand after reading mangas about vampires is that losing the ones you love constantly is as painful as death. You live forever. You see everyone around you dying. Life becomes meaningless. You’ve tried everything. You’ve learned every possible language, you’ve studied every possible science, but it doesn’t matter if you’re alone. You’re just on your own. No one is around you because you’ll stay and they’ll go. At that point living forever becomes your curse.
You may say “nah, at least I’m alive”. Dude, when you will experience someone you know dying you will understand what I mean. And you will be able to imagine other ppl dying. It would be great if all of us could live forever, but now in 2022 it is not possible, fortunately or unfortunately.
All of those who watch this is 2022 will be most likely dead by 2100-2150. Congrats if you read it and you made it to 2200, I’m proud of you. But I guess I’m already dead by that time. It’s strange to say so, but it is most like will be so. I’ll die. And you’ll die. I’m gonna cry because it’s scary. The only key is to save money if you don’t have them, then find a therapist and attend him or her to clear up your mind. This is the best decision I’ve found so far. I hope I’ll get to talk about it with the therapist in the next 2 years, because I’m getting more and more anxious about it each year.
My old friend ones answered me after I’d asked him about his attitude towards death: “I don’t think about it and I don’t see a point of thinking about it and fearing it, because I can’t change it and I will die. I have to think about my LIFE instead of thinking about my DEATH. So, i just don’t think about it. That’s it”. And he is damn right. It (most likely) won’t matter after we die. So not to waste the life we have, it is our duty and responsibility to live lives we want to live.
You want to be a doctor? Be a doctor. You want to quit your university? Quit it. You want to travel around the world. Then hecking book tickets and go.
You’ll say “well, easy to say”. Yes. It’s easier to say. But if you won’t do what you want — when time comes to leave the world of those who are alive — you’ll regret and try to breath as hard as you’ll only be able to and do at least anything to change it. But it’s too late. Time’s up.
This is where we come to the point that we have to do everything to end each and everyday with a thought “I’m good, I’m great, I’m thankful and I’m happy, I won’t regret even if I die right now at the moment of thinking about it”. That’s the key to not regret when it comes to an end.
Thanks for reading this. I had to get into the dialogue with the comment section and the keyboard to calm myself down. I hope you all will live a healthy, happy, long, interesting and unpredictable lives. Rip to all ppl who are not with us and joy to all of those who read this comment. Have a great day and a great life. We’ll all meet alive or dead, but we will definitely meet and this thought comforts me a lot. Thank you♥️

I think it goes like this:Energy cannot be destroyed, but it can be changed. Human beings at the end of the day are energy themselves. And when we die, that energy does not, it just changes form. It evolves. It moves on. And where it leaves us with the concept of the afterlife is in my opinion two scenarios.
1) Is how other people have theorised the afterlife is, that it’s basically like a place of your creation.Your best memories are all there, your loved ones are there to meet you, you can basically do anything that you can do in the real world in this world,only you can do it with a thought.If you want to play video games again, you can do that, if you want to watch old war films all day long(if you want the day night cycle in your own heaven, you can, it’s a world where your imagination doesn’t die).

2)And here it’s the most likely scenario
We are born, then we die, then our energy based life forms just move on to the next cycle(When I mean the next cycle, I mean I’m going with the theory that time is a circle, when the end of time happens, the birth of another one begins, time can be different there, or act the same, we go back to the beginning of our own life again, we bring our own previous experiences from the previous life, not the memories but the lessons, we make different choices, our grandparents could make different choices which results in a different outcome. We might end up being born with a different parent which results in us having different personalities as a result or we might end up being stillborn which you will have to go the next cycle. The cycle keeps going over and over and it doesn’t end, it doesn’t stop.

And here’s the thing, this isn’t the first cycle, you probably had some dreams, or nightmares of previous cycles: a cycle where we end in a nuclear war, or a virus has destroyed us all. The concept of a multiverse could be vastly different here, as instead of them existing in different dimensions, they are merely the next or previous cycle of our lives.

Or it could be a combination of both, we don’t know how this works, people have seen only darkness and other people have seen things and I say, that’s because when we become energy, we can’t see, we can’t hear, but we can think, we can feel, we are one with the universe after all. We could have more than one life in one cycle and we repeat them over and over again in every cycle. Your life is just one many lives you experience in an infinite number of cycles of life and death, the beginning and the end.

I'm going to validate your feelings, sharing your emotions with you, empathizing with you. Your pain is going to be my pain. I'm going to meet you where you're at, at your developmental level. I'm going to forgive you for your mistakes.
I'm going to be patient with you. I'm going to see the good in you even when you don't see the good in yourself. I'm going to be generous and kind. I'm going to give you verbal approval and praise. I'm going to compliment you on your uniqueness. I'm going to keep my promises to you. I'm going to keep my peace with you, avoid conflict with you. I'm going to tell the truth to you. You're going to be able to fully trust me and I'm never going to cash in on that trust. I'm going to see your realness, warts and shadow and all as you truly are. I'm going to deeply appreciate the finite portion of consciousness that you are and I'm going to accept your selfishness whenever you have the urge to be selfish. I just started thinking about this, but I think I feared death mainly because I thought I had a lot to live for. What if you feel like you don't have much to live for (not in a depressing way)? What if you feel like you've experienced enough of life? Or if you realize that what you're experiencing now tends to be circular (experienced over and over) until you die? Why then would you be afraid of death if you feel like you've experienced enough already? I think we all come to a baseline reality; if we go too high, we come back down eventually; if we go too low, we also come back to baseline eventually. If you're at baseline now then why do you think you're going to experience more than just the same baseline? After all, it doesn't matter what you experience or acquire in the future, we will always come back to our baseline. Why be afraid of losing something you've experienced a million times already? I've experienced enough of the same to say that my future will not be much different than it is now, so dying doesn't really bother me. I literally just thought of this and it makes a lot of sense. I know my future will have highs and lows but they are temporary and the majority of my future will be felt through a certain baseline, so I'm not really afraid of not experiencing something I've experienced enough already.

Make no mistake, we fear death for a very good reason, to die, is to disappear, FOREVER. No there won't be a life after death, no there won't be a chance at "resurrecting" you, no there won't be a reincarnation waiting for you.

That "atoms of you will persist", that has to be like the weakest argument ever. I don't care about atoms, I probably have already replaced a good chunk of them since I was born. What I care is what makes me, me, the cloud of information that is housed inside my brain, that is our true nature and who we truly are.
This is why brain death basically means a point of no return, even if we managed to regenerate and regrow your brain again after having it be catastrophically damaged, YOU is gone for good, and another cloud of information will take its place.

Q. Salam dear sister, I’m a person suffering from thanatophobia. I can’t think straight, I really do try to go about my day and do it with so much positivity but I can’t, I’m so scared. I’m always anxious, I get panic attacks.

I don’t know what to do, I over analyze every single thing someone says to me and pick the most negative out of it. I know I have a problem and try to accept it but then my mind starts,the what ifs, what if it’s actually going to happen. Then deep down in my mind somewhere I’ll just convince myself that’s going to happen.

I pray all the time, and I know Allah is the greatest healer, but sometimes I get scared even telling God about my problems. I don’t know what to do again, I have tried everything, I’m scared of talking to my family and friends, because I’m afraid of what they’ll say to me and I’ll take it out of context.

I can’t even think of my future as far as the next day or week because I’m so afraid. This is very hard for me coming here to state my problem, but I know talking about it helps, so I’m here to try everything I can to get myself back to normal.

I would really appreciate it if you could answer me. Thank you so much.

💡 ANSWER


"Hannah Morris"


16 April, 2022


Wa Alaikum Salaam wa Rahmatulahi wa Barakatuh Sister,

This is something that most people experience to some extent. However, you are experiencing it to a level that it is having such a huge impact on your daily life and psychological well being, so it is certainly something that needs addressing.

I would advise that in a case like your own you do get some additional ongoing support to deal with this phobia as it has apparently reached a level that needs some form of clinical intervention. There are some types of therapy available that deal with phobia very specifically that would be useful for you. I would advise that you go to your doctor to get advice on this and referral to the appropriate service.


In the context of this type of counseling I can’t provide ongoing support; but I can give you some tips that I hope will help in the meantime until you are able to get this additional support.


Iꞌm Scared of Death, Please Help! - About Islam


Should Muslim Feel Anxious about Death?


Alhamdulilah as a Muslim, you have lots of solutions at your fingertips that should help at least take the edge off these difficulties.

Increase Your Good Deeds


As I said, fear of death is something we probably all experience to some extent. It’s not a pleasant feeling to be so anxious, however, there are ways that we can use it to our benefit, particularly as Muslims. We know that death is surely coming to us, and we know that when that time comes, we must face our deeds. This can be very scary for everyone as we have all committed some level of sin in our life.


However, with this knowledge, we can use this to push to do good to ensure that our scale of good deeds is heavy on the day that it really matters. Use this as an opportunity to increase your good deeds. This may in the form of increasing your acts of ibadah, doing more voluntary prayer and reading more Quran for example.


Al Hadi - The Source of All Guidance


Al Hadi - The Source of All Guidance


Additionally, use this as a motivation to restrain from sin. However, at the same time, do not lose hope in Allah’s Mercy, in the knowledge that He loves to forgive and He will forgive you as long as you continue to turn to Him for guidance and in repentance. Find comfort in this and this will help to reduce the anxiety pscyhologically, but also the physiological effects of feeling anxious too.


Remember Allah

Sometimes, the feeling that you’re having possibly can be attributed to the whispers of Shaytan, especially if they are distracting you from Allah and turning to Him. Whether it is or not, there is no harm in making sure to tackle this also by keeping Allah in mind all the time and repelling Shaytan.


Make sure not to neglect your morning and evening adhkar to protect you from this, as well as doing all the necessary duas as you do different acts during the day right down to those you say before you enter the bathroom and so on. This ensures Allah is always close and Shaytan is not given the space to enter your mind with intrusive thoughts.


May Allah guide you out of this distressing situation that you are in and may you find great comfort in His remembrance.

None of these things provide comfort. Especially the idea of "our" atoms staying around. Think about this:
"Non-existence Before birth" was followed by a consciousness that's being done by a brain. Brains will do consciousnesses after the one reading this ends. And so if death is also non-existence, then death—as "non-existence before birth" was—will also be followed by a consciousness that's being done by one of the brains that are alive.

And so death will be followed by yet another consciousness just as "non-existence before birth" was, due to a brain doing consciousness... This is called Generic Subjective Continuity, and it doesn't provide comfort either, because it means that your end could be followed by the consciousness that's being caused by the brain in the body of an animal that's experiencing being eaten alive.. or the brain of a criminal experiencing a life sentence... And so on.

Maybe the heat death of the universe will one day end all consciousnesses forever, but until then... There's going to be billions of consciousnesses lined up after the one that's reading this ends.

But if somehow consciousness is done by a brain at some far off time after the heat death of the current universe... Then there's no end to experience ever... All periods of time whenever there's no brains doing consciousness in the universe are not experienced - only experience is experienced... Kind of sucks... But it gives us yet another great reason to be kind to all sentient beings, and teach this to others, so they have a great reason to be kind if for some reason they are not convinced by any of the other reasons people have for being kind.

CW: somewhat graphic. I don't mind if no one sees this, I just feel better getting it out.

I lost my cousin recently due to a violent crime. He was shot point blank in the head and wasn't breathing by the time his friends got him to the hospital. Doctors couldn't save him. He went out with his friends on a normal night to get some fast food and smoke some weed. No different than any other day. And he ended up dead at 19.

At the time, my friends asked me if I was ok. I said I was. I hadn't been close w him since we were kids, and I'm now 22, why wouldn't I be ok? I went to his service. It lasted the whole weekend and I got to really process and feel the grief of my family. The regrets they held about how they treated him. I got drunk and asked my friends to sit on call w me.

I cried and I screamed and I ranted and I told them I loved them and I poured my heart out about all the times I felt like I'd hurt them or been cruel, of all the things I regretted. Not once, in my drunken state (which all my friends will tell you is when I'm most honest) did I care about myself. I was trying to make amends with them. To not have any regrets like I did w my cousin.

It's hard to find the words, but hearing everyone's stories in the comments, made me feel like I did the right thing. Even if I was drunk, they weren't. They heard me. They listened to me. I'm scared of dying, but I'm even more scared of being alone, in death and in life. Owning up to shit I've done, telling my friends how much they mean to me. I feel better than I have in years.

I don't know what the point of this comment was. I just feel so much less alone, so much more human after that night. I fear death all the time, but only when I'm alone. When I'm with people, I sometimes think "I could die happy right now." So I'm clinging to that feeling. To the contentedness. And I love all you glorious humans. I love humanity. We're not doing so bad. One day at a time y'all. We got this.

I don't find this video particularly comforting, except for the realization that many other people share this fear of death. I still experience anxiety over it, although I do try to rationalize myself out of it. We popped into existence after billions of years and suddenly here we are on this strange planet in the middle of a giant universe. Just like how billions of years passed before us like nothing, after we die, eternity passes by in an instant. And who knows what could happen on the other side of eternity?

I see no reason why our universe in our plane of existence should be the only one. And with infinite possible universes in an eternal existence, life and consciousness must arise in all sorts of strange and fascinating forms. According to our understanding of physics, there's a non-zero chance that a bunch of atoms will spontaneously arrange themselves into the exact shape of me, with all my thoughts and memories. And of course any tiny variation of those memories and shape, and so on... So whatever forms come to be in the future, none of them will ever be "me", but since I am basically no different from anyone else, why does it matter whether it's "me" or not?

5:36 "We should work to allow people to lead happier & longer lives."



I think this is a philosophical contradiction. If death is what makes life meaningful, then the best way to bring meaning to people's lives is to help them die, which is an absurd statement. If a longer life makes life more meaningful, then to bring meaning to people's lives is to care for their wellbeing and make them live forever. Therefore, living things that live forever have infinite meaning, and finite things that live have either no meaning or finite meaning, and dead things are infinitely meaningless. Death is what makes life meaningless. If we have the power to create everlasting meaning in life, we must also have the power to abolish death.

This refutes 7:16 "we can choose to have a meaningful life," but only if we have immortality. However, one can interpret that the fear of death makes life meaningful, but why fear what is impending, like fearing puberty? If it is because of survival instinct, why can't we evolve to have longer life spans if death is the ultimate predator? Therefore, the fear of death is not only meaningless, but it is a perfectly rational feeling to have. I find it strange how we govern our possessions against covetous thieves who only take what they ought, yet we freely give our souls away to the thief of death that destroys everything you know and love.
Why live life to the fullest and not the emptiest? The happy and the sad, rich and poor, the successful and failures, are but forgotten vapors anyway. And as long as there is no life after death, the world should have every reason to commit suicide. Surely death is life's greatest quandary; the enemy of existence. Correct me if this logic is not bulletproof.

At the age of 22 I had a near death experience. My lungs closed up due to overuse of the wrong inhaled steroid (asthma inhaler.) long story short I ended up blacking out and being carried out of my house by firefighters. They gave me multiple hits of adrenaline but I was still not breathing…I ended up being unconscious and without oxygen for a few minutes. Luckily the hospital was next to my
house and an entire team of incredible doctors/nurses were able to resuscitate me. During the time leading up to it, being conscious of the fact that my lungs were closing up and I was truly facing the possibility of dying…was terrifying…I pissed myself…sweating profusely…and defecated trying DESPERATELY to draw a breath. It kept getting tighter and tighter until it was like breathing through a juice box straw that’s clogged with mud. Eventually I just felt weightless and no sensation and then….darkness… and it was the most peaceful feeling I’ve ever felt in my life. I no longer felt this “fear” of death. I was okay with it. During the period of unconsciousness it was as if I was watching myself from third person telling myself to not give up…to keep trying to get a breath…because I knew I’d miss my loved ones and that I was way too young to die. I kept fighting. I woke up luckily and it changed my life forever. On one hand I have an intense appreciation for life but at the same time…I look at my girlfriend whom I plan to marry…and I get choked up…because I know that we all die and eventually I’ll come to that same place of darkness…except I won’t be as strong and I’ll slip into it forever. Death is easy. Its the life you leave behind that is hard.

Death is the cessation of consciousness. Consciousness is what allows us to live and experience reality including human emotion and sensation. It does not matter if life is a simulation, what matters is what is right in front of us. The here and now. Your loved ones, families, pets, etc. When you die, you lose that. That is why it is so sad. However, death is not permanent, it's a state of unconsciousness without being conscious. I would rather live a life of experiences both good and bad than just end it right there and then. This is why I will never consider suicide. Because its the journey that matters, not the destination. The destination is death.

There is no reason to fear death. Death and I shall never exist at the same time. As long as I exist, there is no death. When death exists, I do not exist. It is one or the other, and never both at the same time. There is only a sense of loss that is felt by the living. Those we leave behind will miss us. We will only be remembered for about 2 generations. My children will remember me, and perhaps if I'm lucky, my grandchildren will too. But that's all. A mere 50-70 years after we are gone, we are completely forgotten, and we disappear into eternity.

These are the living years. They are few, and they go by fast. Savor every day, and live in the now, for it is all that I have, and all there ever will be.

It can also be stated that the reason we think they deserve to be electrocuted is to avoid dealing with the fact that there is nothing you could do to help them. So we need o become callous to avoid suffering ourselves and to avoid expending energy on saving them until we wind up in the same place. It's a way to rationalize one's own suffering in the presence of others, but it is also unnatural for us to deal with such suffering. Before the advent of agriculture we lived very low stress lives for if life had been so harsh stress wouldn't be such a big deal-but it is. We are a highly social species and we did not evolve to see others in pain without the ability to end their suffering or comfort them. Studies like that prove only that we did not evolve for it. The advent of agriculture is also when the fear of death became primary in human consciousness and something to be feared. Yes there is an instinctual component but a lot of the fear of death is also culturally induced to make us materialistic-or religious. In reality we haven't been living longer but we've only made the process of dying longer. Our ancestors actually lived well into their 70s, 80s and 90s. Don’t fear death.  There is eternal life.  Seek the right destination.  Everybody wants to live forever.  And that is possible through God and heaven.  Death, and the fear of it, and the illusion of it can be very consuming.  But take a step back and put everything into perspective.  This physical world was created.  It was created by God.  God is not physical, and there is not a set of hands creating everything, so therefore God is a separate realm.  And obviously so, a way more powerful realm.  That means that the spiritual world is the real world , and way stronger.  And if the spiritual world is the real world, then all this life and love and emotion inside of me must be my soul.  As it obviously is not born of physicality and atomic molecules.  Our physical make up is no different than clay, or dust, or water, etc......  and when’s the last time dust, or clay, or water ever showed any kind of emotional bond.  So, where’s the source of these feelings?  The soul.  The unseen.  The most powerful force in the world.  So, now let’s go back to the fear of death.  To me at least, it seems irrelevant and illusory. And the physical death is not what is to be feared.  But rather is one worthy of eternal life in heaven.  And not hell.

I just fear not getting to experience everything I want to experience. Even though I have imagined everything in my head, what I'd like to experience, and I know that that is as real as this life (if it truly all just ends one day for us or the entire universe, who says "reality" is more real than your fantasies), I still just always fear that I've been wasting time. I wasted time not starting the things I wanted to start and now that I did, my demon, health anxiety, is telling me that after all the tests I have gotten, this new thing will be the thing that they have missed all along (and when it turns out to be nothing, I wonder what the next thing to panic over will be). So I'm trying to see past just the health aspect of my anxiety and am trying to get to the source. Is it death? Because I do fear it. I used to not, back when I was more spiritual. Now I'm more practical and I fear death and there not being anything after it. I used to believe in multiple lives. But then I got into science and real world problems have held me very close to earth. Now I feel like I've lost my faith in there being a plan. I fear wasting time in this life because I love this life, I want to experience so much still, I'm not asking for a lot. But also I want there to be more to this. I want to see my family members again, see my past pets and friends. I want to be reborn, even if I don't remember this life. I used to think my soul is eternal and has learned from all of these lives and I in some way still believe that with my heart and soul, but my brain is making me doubt that. I would rather live in ignorant bliss believing what some might consider hokus pokus talk, rather than be ultra realistic and think we're all just nothing, come from nothing and will become nothing. If there's an end to us and the Universe, what's the point at all? And what's worse, feeling everything all at once or feeling nothing at all? I can't decide if I'd rather have my overly active anxious brain that finds meaning in everything or a dull depressive brain that doesn't think there's any meaning at all. Idk what to do with my thoughts. Anyway, thanks for reading my diary entry for today. And I had such a good day before I googled some symptoms. Maybe that's the point? Just have a good day. And then another. And then another. Until there are no more days. I still refuse to believe there is no afterlife but, maybe I should focus on being alive right now rather than thinking of being dead one day. <3

We are , You are Consciousness taking form temporarily as this form. You get to eventually change ‘costume’ but your real Self will have a realization before the next to examine more wholly what all just happened. You (the REAL you) us not concerned about shedding this human form. You were, are and will ALWAYS be. Is that exhausting or liberating?

Surely you can sense this at moments in life. I would say in the meantime, try to not compare your experiences with others. For instance, you may see or hear a story that frightens you, certain tragedies. But you have no idea the mystery, the unseen reason or meaning behind these things. Religion is one way to approach but need not be divorced from any science we have access to at any time. When you can realize this self (sans ego) before transitioning, you will know what is real and what is not. “Die before you die— and find that there is no Death’” It’s a doorway not an end.

We are our consciousness. When our brain dies, our consciousness dies with it; our unique personality, likes, knowledge, memories, etc, it all dies, and we cease to exist as us . No religion can really guarantee you that you will continue to exist as you after you die, because if you really think about it, it is quite illogical and impossible and unproven to say the least. Basically, when we die, we cease to exist forever as the unique person that we are and know; as we are our consciousness, and our consciousness is the product of our brain, which needs a living body to function. Without a working brain, we are nothing. No thoughts, no sight, no hearing, no sense of smell, touch, or of being alive; just nothing.
So yes, people, be scared of death. I am.

sorry but this was kinda intellectually lazy. not because those high school-level scientific facts weren't interesting, but because there's really no coherent argument here. you're letting your own love for scientific trivia get in the way of relating them to existential dread. the idea that your cells go on without you has no real narrative relation to, for instance, the argument that death gives life meaning. those are just a collection of facts and moral perspectives that aren't elaborated on or connected properly. a lot of these "looking at death / morality / religion / etc from a SCIENTIFIC perspective :)" videos don't say anything more meaningful than "science is cool, universe big, you small but important" wrapped in a handful of psuedointellectual platitudes. bringing up a single study that most people don't want to live forever does nothing to help those that do.

as to, for instance, the specific argument of "your atoms will go on" - any intellectually honest person should KNOW that's not what fear of death is about. to most people, the fear of death exists because people generally care about themselves as a living, conscious ego, not what happens to cells that are no longer a part of you. just like you don't really care what happens to fingernails once they're clipped because they were technically a part of you once. they're not anymore. so that doesn't help at all, and no amount of vaguely "spiritualism-for-science-nerds!" platitudes about how Big the Universe and Your Brain Are and How Its All Connected And We're All In This Together are comforting unless you already believe in said platitudes as giving your life any sense of meaning. the only helpful thing you said was that science can't actually give your life meaning, because its void of moral and philosophical insight on its own.

Here’s an interesting paradox:

From what we can observe our consciousness is made by atoms alone. Considering how much movement and change of state with the atoms in our bodies, no information is ever truly saved within us. Our memories change all the time and the only reason life still makes sense to us is because our brains are programmed to create meaning.

We think we can agree on how we observe the world, but in reality it’s just our minds being insane. You know how it’s possible to have a crazy dream, yet while in dreaming it everything makes sense to you? Well, same thing could be going on while awake. Which means we do not know about anything and therefore can not know about atoms themselves, and there comes the paradox

That... or our consciousness is not only made out of atoms. It could be something divine.

This is a subject I think about all the time, and it has often left me feeling depressed, but here are some of my thoughts on this.

I think there is a difference between 'you' and consciousness. You are conscious, however what you are as a person, whoever you are, is a configuration. In fact, a human is a form of life. A form of being. When you die, the configuration breaks down. Consciousness however is different. First of all, we need to quit separating ourselves from the rest of the universe. A human being is as much a part of the physical world as a parking lot is. In other words, there is no 'out there.' You are a part of the earth and its total mass. You arent separate of the physical world, but rather another part of it, like anything be it a tree, or a rock. Or a car. Additionally, while you are cojsidered living, everything that makes up you is non living. The iron in your blood is the same iron that steel is refined from. The water in your body which constitutes 70 percent of your mass is the same water you would find on a comet floating about in space. Are either of those alive? No. Neither one of them or anything in you. You are an animated object made of inanimate material.

Consciousness arises from matter. But how? How can a state of inate awareness arise from physical matter? There has to be some property within matter that gives rise to consciousness. In this case, consciousness is like matter and energy. It is fundamental. If so, then like matter and energy, it cannot be created or destroyed. It can be converted. In this case the awareness isn't lost at death, however the person, the memories, all of that are lost as those are a configuration. Without any memories existence is a novelty. In my opinion, we are all part of one big cosmic mind, like neurons in a brain.

I don't fear death. I think being uncomfortable in suffering during death is the issue.I've been at death's door holding the scyth quite a few times and feel I can speak on it. Feeling suffocation is not pleasant at least that is what my mind tells me death is.I know it is a lengthier process of cellular death,necrosis,rigidity,organ failure, etc but that is all I can think about. I am tired of living.Don't get me wrong,life is a gift but it can be a curse if you suffer through it. I just can't seem to catch a break or a breath before struck with calamity.Before I have time to even blink,I am hit with tragedy.I am doing everything right and still going through injustice just for helping folks.I am trying to keep a hope for life's possibilities.I had that zest and vigor for life,yet when the hope goes,it's a wrap. I've been through much on this planet and I can't say I'll miss the suffering.For some it gets better,for others we just suffer from cradle to grave. I made every effort to earn my place here.I am excited about having rest as I've been living off four hours of sleep a day for years.I look forward to not having to deal with my good name & reputation being slandered. Death is the great equalizer.I won't miss daily dehumanization or ongoing civil rights violations.I won't miss the cruelty of people's jealousies, assumptions,speculations,hearsay,rumors,bias,prejudices,ignorance or unkindness.I won't miss injustice. The longer you stay here you see folks indifference & coldness. One can only play the best hand dealt to them.The most loving thing my "parents"could have done for me was abort me. I don't believe any good person should suffer and if need be have an end to such suffering.We all are not guaranteed a good life,but at the very least we can choose a great death.Death is a certainty for all.

It is deeply irresponsible of any content creators - but especially content creators with such a large following - to spread wrong information to their audience, which is exactly what the people behind this channel have done with this video.

The reality is that death is not necessarily inevitable because of advanced technologies; rejuvenation research has shown that age-related damages that occur in the body are amenable to medical intervention, and while such medicines to actually keep the elderly perfectly healthy haven't been developed yet, they may very well be soon (Aubrey de Grey from the SENS Research Foundation think there's a 50/50 chance of people reaching longevity escape velocity by the year 2036), and cryonics (which is a medical experiment that has all of the evidence in the literature supporting its feasibility) exists today and provides critically ill people with a realistic chance of being revived in the future.

Unfortunately, neither cryonics nor rejuvenation research was mentioned in this video; instead, the host decided to ignore both a promising medical experiment and the progress being made in the lab to keep people healthy indefinitely, and the host decided to try to justify death (which is disgusting), but despite all of the clichés and coping mechanisms used in this awful video, technological progress has been made and will only continue to advance; I recommend everybody get a cryonics membership and help support the research relevant to biostasis and geroscience.

It's videos like this where I start to understand a lot of untapped angst in western culture with regards to death.

A lot of cultures have historically been built around allowing their adherents to come to terms not only with death, but also the gradual decay of your mortal form. Not only is death, the time when you are completely gone, a scary thing to think about, but there is also the process of decay that you go through in the best case.

When I was in middleschool I became nearsighted, it did not dawn on me that I would never see clearly through my natural eyes until I die. If I get surgery, that may only speed up the decay in other ways (becoming farsighted, etc.) A couple of days ago I realized I couldn't see in the dark as well as I could.

Thinking about my hands is horrifying. They are my connection to everything, to create and do everything I love, to cook and clean, to pet my cats, to hold my family, to play games, to write. But one day they will be gone, they will either be completely worn out or I will lose them to some injury. The best case scenario is they are replaced by something that replicates them.

In western thought we try to come to terms with death itself by attaching it, as older cultures did, to a higher purpose. There is comparatively little to allow us to accept our inevitable decay.

In any case, if we're all being honest, death and dying does not really feel like something mundane and natural, it feels overwhelming, it's very sad to think that one day you won't get to wake up and do all your favorite things one day. It's not something anyone should go through alone.

In order for their to be light something has to burn. Daylight is the product of the sun burning. The stars in the night sky is a product of other stars burning. The lightbulbs in your house can only light up because they too are burning. We are like a torch that keeps getting passed on. The match might burn out quickly but the candle you lit with it will burn for far longer. Death is an extinguishing of your light, your flame so to speak. There is nothing scary about that. Anxiety is a result of neurons firing...yeah firing, like fire. If the sun knew it was going to burn out eventually it might try burning even hotter to try and compensate, but those that know anything about stars know that a star that burns hotter lives a shorter lifespan. Anxiety isn't always something we can control, especially if you have OCD like I do (that shit gets bonkers at times) but at least there is some solace in knowing that one day the neurons causing our anxiety will cease to fire, and our anxiety will cease as well. For the time being we can do our best to live a life of happiness and do what we can to keep anxiety at a minimum.

I hope reincarnation isn't real. No way in hell would I want to experience life on this earth over and over, even though I wouldn't remember any of my past lives. When it comes down to it, I'm actually very lucky to have the life I do, and if reincarnation were real, I'd fear getting stuck with a real shitty next life. I was into the new-agey spiritual stuff for a while and looked up a lot of stuff about souls and reincarnation. Real interesting, but kind of a bummer in a way...because according to that, our souls have to go through challenges here on earth in order to evolve, whereas right now at this point in time, I'm kind of hoping we just have this one life and that's it. After that, it's just blank. Emptiness. It's not like we'll feel it or sense it in any way if that really is the end of our consciousness, if our consciousness just flips off like a light switch and then it's just nothing.

But at the same time, I definitely believe there's more to us than just our physical bodies. We still don't even fully understand what consciousness is and how it works. I believe in science and am super into astronomy and astrophysics, but at the same time, I'm also kind of spiritual and believe there's so much to the universe & to existence in general that we don't know about/will likely never know about that can't be explained by science as we currently understand it. It's funny. Sometimes I vacillate between strictly adhering to science and believing all of our lives and the emergence of the human species in general were just by pure chance and we're nothing in the grand scheme of the universe, and that one day even the universe itself will go dark and eventually die...but who knows, there are scientific theories out there about a multiverse, or maybe the universe will eventually be reborn. Then other times, I lean on the more spiritual side and think "but there HAS to be more to this existence than just life, death, then nothingness." But maybe that's just my human egocentrism speaking? If our consciousness is energy and energy can neither be created nor destroyed, where does that energy go when we die? Since we're all made of star stuff, I guess we started out as just elements of the universe before we were born, and after we die, our energy just merges back into the universe at large? Or maybe that energy is what some of us call a soul and that soul goes somewhere we find out about only when we die. Who knows. Anyway, I have to stop 'cause clearly I've written more than enough and this stuff can get me going for hours.

Forgot to add: I talked about getting "stuck" with a shitty next life if reincarnation were real, but according to the new age theories, our souls specifically choose what our lives will be like before we begin a new cycle aka life. Meaning we apparently choose our parents, general events/challenges in our life, etc, all in the quest to evolve our souls. Basically, according to this belief, we've agreed to our lives in advance; it's just that we can't remember doing any of that when we're in our mortal bodies.
We also have pooping in common, don't ever forget that.

I remember going under anesthesia for the first time.   Sure, before the procedure I knew I was waking back up, but the point is during the operation I would be experiencing the closest thing I ever could to death... a dreamless sleep.    When I woke up after, I had the strangest thought...  that was so relaxing, can  someone give me another shot?   Lol.   Its very different from normal sleep.. where you vaguely recall some nightmare or stressful situation.   It was a total worry-free time.  Im not saying I want to die, no way.  But this experience makes me feel a little less fearful about death.

I ponder death as many do.   Ultimately, I think this way:   how did I feel when the pyramids were being built?   How about when Rome was at it's height?  Or for that matter when dinosaurs were rulers of this planet?    My reply is I felt just fine...  wasn't sad, depressed, worried, angry or the least bit fearful.    Thinking this way, it makes me feel a bit better.

The probability of you even existing right now is infinitesimally small, yet here you are. Now think about this. The probability of you existing again after death, on one of the trillions of planets in the universe, is also infinitesimally small but not zero. The logical conclusion is that given enough time we all will live again.

Everyone is entitled to say whatever they believe about death. However, there has only ever been one person in history who emphatically spoke on this subject - Jesus of Nazareth, commonly known as Jesus Christ. Many have heard of the name Jesus but not many have seriously considered the astonishing claims he made. Fewer still are people who tried to examine if there are evidence to support these radical claims. Jesus said: "I AM the resurrection and the life. Anyone who believes in me will live, even after dying. Everyone who lives in me and believes in me will never ever die" (John 11:25,26). Again Jesus said: "I AM the way, the truth, and the life. No one can come to the Father except through me" (John 14:6). So Jesus claimed that he alone has the power to grant immortality to every person who believes in him.

Jesus Christ rose from the dead - this is the foundation of Christianity (1 Corinthian 15: 12-17). There is historical evidence to support this claim.


If you are searching for answers to the four big questions of human existence - origin, meaning, morality, and destiny, you owe it to yourself to find out who Jesus is. Your eternity will never be the same.

My uneducated guess is death exists because endless life has no value. If the spirit exist and our consciousness continue after death suffering and pain would teach and mature our spirits. I imagine our spirits live out many lifetimes in order to adapt and become better. Every living being learns at least one valuable lesson in their lifetime then dies and gets reborn then rinse and repeat. Perhaps even complete monsters are that way because they're learning something important perhaps they're young souls who've only recently stepped up from living as animals. Why are people ok with dying? I always hear, ”everyone dies someday.” Why isn't the main priority for humanity to develop ways to live forever? I'm not talking about medicine to slow our body's death; I'm talking about uploading our brain/consciousness into something that doesn't decay over time like our bodies. Yeah, maybe that sounds like Syfy, but so did cars and cell phones. The best scientists in the world die, but what if all the well-known scientists were still alive today? Humanity is set back with every death of a person who made life-changing discoveries. Some day humans will live forever, maybe in 10000 years, but if we were born then we would live forever. Since we live now we can't live forever. I'm not scared of death. I just don't want it to happen because someday other humans will live forever, so as self-centered as it sounds, I'm jealous that this generation won't live forever, but others after us will. I'm also upset that people treat death as something that's supposed to happen. Who said we were supposed to die, and why aren't we figuring out a way to really live?

I believe for most people death isn't actually the scary part. The scary part is what comes after. Is it eternal darkness? Is it the same thing before we were born when you just could not feel even light and my head hurts at 3 AM thinking about what life was like before our birth. Is it a place like heaven or hell where people live eternally being immortal. The scarier and most depressive part is thinking about your teenage years, your years as a child, the years you spent making your dreams come true and all those people you had for friends and those you had a crush on. Your parents, your relationships. Everyone aging slowly and finally fading away. You don't know if you going to meet them again in an afterlife. I feel very depressed when thinking about my parents and the girl that I like just kicking the bucket at some point. All those moments with each person just ending. All that fear motivates me so bad to become a researcher and attempt prolong lives. You may feel sad and scared with these thoughts. I do. But we should believe in God and that he takes care of us. Think about that. We are the only intellectual species on this planet and haven't found any other species similar to our capabilities. We evolved and survived our predators and harsh environments. We cured all the diseases that striked us and move on curing more. We survived wars that could end our existence. We have discovered planets that are similar to ours but only our own planet hosts the most wonderful thing in the entire universe that is called LIFE. Our will to survive and keep moving through the years is limitless. When we see a danger our survival instinct kicks in and we try to save our lives at all costs. We have to believe that nothing is just random. That there is something supreme that guides us and protects us but doesn't show it directly. We have to believe that we don't come in life randomly. That we have a task to accomplish and a life to live at its best. And at the end we finally get awarded

Man sinned, and  therefore, could no longer be in God's presence. God is holy and has no sin nor can he be around sin. Man lives on this Earth and must find forgiveness for all of his sins, believe in God, and accept his Son, Jesus Christ, as his Savior. God sent his son into the world to be a sacrifice for the sins of the world. He was sinless, but he took the "death sentence" that we all deserved, for us. We must put our faith in Jesus and when we do, we will be 'born again'. Yes, we were born once of the flesh (our moms gave us birth) and at some point in our lives, we must be born a second time, spiritually. This new birth give us the ability to never experience DEATH. The Holy Spirit comes to live within a person who has been born again. It's quite an amazing experience and for us who have been filled with God's spirit, it is hard to explain to others what this is all about. This search for the meaning of life, that this man explains that our brains look for, is God!  Yes, we all die and our bodies return to dust and our spirit (God's breath of life) returns to Him, but those who have come to a belief in Jesus, while living on this Earth, will live forever and those who don't will die and perish forever.  They will be as if they never existed. Those who believe in Jesus will awaken from their sleep of death, when Jesus returns to earth in the future, and be given an immortal body.  This is the "good news".  You don't have to die.  You can live for all eternity!

We actually die 4 times. There is the death of self, the death of memory, the death of history and your genetic death.
That is, your personal death, the death of the last person who knew you personally, and the death of the last person who ever heard of you. This may include physical records, so even if no one is alive who ever heard of you, so long as there is a physical record of your life, then you have not yet experienced historical death. Genetic death is the death of your last descendant.

My authority is NOT my own opinion. My authority is the English King James Bible, which is the inspired and preserved Word of God. Don't make the mistake of dismissing it (which you have probably been trained to do) without first checking it out.

The Bible says that you do not just stop when you die. Your soul goes either to heaven with the Lord, or into hell, which is a place of torment in flames. (See Luke 16:19-31.) Hebrews 9:27 says "It is appointed unto men once to die, but after this the judgment."

This is definitely not a satisfying reply to this question. Sure memories of us of our cells will live on, but why would we care if we are DEAD. Under the assumption seemingly made in this video that death is the end of our existence anywhere of both our body and our conscious, we would not be conscious to care if memories of us or our cells or whatever live on. The only time that answer would comfort anyone is while they are still alive, and they may see that it  is totally not an answer to the question. Choosing to not dread on death and focusing on making a meaningful life is just avoiding the problem. Why would a feeling of significance about the quantity of our neurons be a reason to not fear death in any way? The two things are unrelated and we're all going to die anyway. Death will always be looming until we die, whether we accept it or not. What I think is this: before this world or life or anything existed, if somehow someone was to tell you that life was going to exist and we were going to have a world perfectly designed for us, you would think they are crazy. There is nothing. How could something exist. (I know this is impossible to happen, because we would not have existed, but you get the point). But we do exist. Life exists. That seems like a crazy statement. Anything exists, but how? Even more, how is it that what does exist is perfectly designed for us? The sun's photosphere is over 10,000 degrees f and we are far enough away with an atmosphere that protects against just the right amount of rays for the light to ripen our tomatoes. Going back to the point about the absurdity that life exists, if someone were to tell you that life exists after this world, why would you think it is absurd? We live in a perfect world (were not nothing anymore), so how could an afterlife not exist? You are probably in a building right now, so how do you know there was a builder? If you see a painting, how do you know there was a painter? Obviously the existence of the building or painting points to a builder or painter. It couldn't have come out of nothing and just existed, that would be scientifically impossible. In my understanding, creation, better yet perfect creation, is absolute evidence for a creator. Do you believe nothing created everything? That is scientifically impossible. In my opinion, the only way that makes sense is that there is something bigger than this world and this world's laws of physics. God is the creator, who is who He is. This is why anything exists, because of Him. This is why this world is perfectly designed, because of Him. Another piece of evidence that points to Him is that He prophesied through prophets about what would happen in the future of this creation He made. Those prophecies are recorded in the Bible, and there are about 2,500 of them. 2,000 of the 2,500 prophecies have been fulfilled perfectly to the letter. They have been fulfilled as perfect as this world was for us, until sin entered the world. The remaining 500 are about the future and will tell us what will occur in the future of this wonderful creation. The point is that God also gave us a set of laws that point to His perfect character, but going against the laws is ruining this wonderful world He created for us. We have all went against these laws and due to this, the Bible says we all deserve death. We don't deserve life, because we have ruined this world and gone against God's only commands for us. God is a righteous judge and has to judge according to the violations of the law we committed. However, God also loves us so much that He came to the world Himself to live a perfect life and die as a sacrifice for anyone who accept the sacrifice. If we repent (turn away) and trust in God with our life, He can lead us to everlasting life due to Jesus' perfect sacrifice. One of the points of this video is that death makes life great. The only reason we wouldn't want to live here forever is that this world is no longer perfect. It has been corrupted by sin and we are cut off from God. I don't know exactly what heaven will be like, but I know it will be better than anything this world can offer and an eternity with God. God bless you all and please think about repenting and turning to God before it is too late. It has saved me from the fear of death and changed my life for the absolute better, so I encourage you to read the Gospels, pray, and seek God's character so we can all understand this world and God better.

You Die at the End: Meditations on Mortality and the Human Condition, is William Ferraiolo’s attempt to contemplate a few perennial challenges of the human condition.

An excerpt:

“You know that decency and virtue are infinitely more valuable than any object or condition for which you might consider trading them away. Virtue is not for sale. It cannot be purchased. It is, quite literally, priceless. You know that you are far better off with good character and with your dignity intact, than you could ever be with any amount of money, fame, or power purchased at the expense of shattered virtue and degraded personhood. A wealthy miscreant is a miscreant nonetheless. “

The problem is that everyone fears death, and treats it like a disease, even if it is coming closer to us by the millionth of a second.

Maybe this extreme fear of death forces people who are suffering and not living the life that they want to continue to strive in this vicious circle.

This is how I look at it:

We didn’t choose to live. We have no idea why we are here. Of course, some people will say that God created us and that our souls chose to come to this Earth. But, how do they know? Exactly: they don’t. Religion is just a way to make us feel better about living mostly miserable lives – that’s why I believe that ANY religion is a form of madness, but that’s not what my comment is about.

From the moment we are born, we are told what to be like, how to behave, what to do, what not to do… and three years into the start of our lives, we are put in school, where we must acquiesce to a figure of power, representing society in general: a teacher. Most of us get knocked down, bullied, ridiculed, emotionally or physically abused; by people around us, and sometimes even by our own family. We are told to work hard, even though most of us would rather do other things but are told that if we don’t work hard we will not make it in life (what the hell). Then, after having busted our asses off, we have to get a job – or be a slave – save money and die. Most of us won’t have time to travel or do the things that we really want. I could go on and on and on about this, but then I’d probably have to write an entire book!

My final question is: what’s the point?

Go to school → get a job → work for 40 years → retire → die.

Honestly, why suffer? Why not skip the middle part? We never chose to come here, isn’t it logical for us to have the choice to live or die?

Of course, there is one exception: if you have children, then you must live because it is, in my opinion, a way to show that you are satisfied with this life, and abandoning your children is horrible.

My fear is a little different from those in the comments. I'm not afraid of what happens afterwards, I'm not afraid of death itself. Through spiritual AND quantum study, I have learned that the spirit lives on. We leave our physical bodies but our conciousness absolutely continues. Believing fully in that keeps me grounded. I know death is not the end. But even if it is not, life itself, feels fleeting. When I was 20ish I had an experience with my heart that felt as if it could have killed me. Ever since then I have had heart related issues that I know are partly anxiety, and also partly from what happened that day. Point in case, heart palpitations. I feel them all the time. I never felt them before that day. I'm still in my 20's and every year I have an experience that puts me in the hospital. Most of those times,  it is chest pain, half my body going numb, pain that radiates to my shoulder, heat in my head, sharp pains in my body, even blood pressure spikes and signs of clotting (according to the doctors). All types of things and it just feels like my body is ill equipped for life. I know these things are WHY I have anxiety about death. I know these things could kill me. I hear these things could be all be in my head. (Doubt its ALL in my head though. My EKG's are sketchy.) But knowing that my heart could "attack me" or I could have a blood clot travel to my heart or brain or lungs and just kill me, are why I fear death. Those things scare the shit out of me because they are so far out of my control. Because of that, I eat healthy and live an active lifestyle. Yet I continue to experince these episodes in which it feels as if I am having a medical emergency. I JUST found a good person who wants to love me and possibly marry me. And I keep thinking how bad I feel for them. Knowing that if we were to get married and have kids, I would die first for sure, and leave them all behind. OR I could die sooner than later, and die before I've experienced a life of loving someone and someone loving me! These are things that keep me from living my life to it's full potential. Why I dropped out of college. Why I settled in a low wage job, why I have few attachments. Why I have roommates and refuse to live alone even though I want to. This crippling fear has altered the course of my life and that in itself, frustrates the hell out of me. Why cant I just NOT have the things happen. Then at least I could try to ignore my thoughts. But everytime I feel that numbness in half my body or those heart palpitations that take the wind out of me, I go back to that thinking everytime. I've taken it as my cost of living. Maybe it is a karmic pay off. If that's the case, fine. Just please dont kill me before 50- is all I ask.

See there's one problem I have with nothingness. While it does bother me as an individual, I will ignore these feelings in my little paragraphs.

There is no scientific evidence for anything. This whole preconception that nothingness in death is the "smart" option doesn't make sense. You don't have any evidence for such claims. So that means if you believe you become a unicorn after death or something, that's just as valid as believing that there is nothing after death.

Another thought I have is that an afterlife wouldn't be so strange to me. I mean think about it. The universe is so wacky. Particles that exist in two places at once, how the big bang was triggered, the different dimensions (2D, 3D, 4D) etc. To me, afterlife doesn't even sound weird at all in comparison to much weirder and wackier stuff in the universe. Reality is much more magical than any human could make up

Another thing is that what makes a living thing living? You and your chair share the same atoms. You could make the argument that life comes from all the biological stuff and stuff like that, but if you inject genetic material into a chair, it doesn't just spring up and start dancing. There is something that we are missing about what makes life conscious and self aware.

Energy doesn't die. It turns into a different form of energy sure, but it doesn't die. Information changes as well, but doesn't get destroyed.

Science doesn't explain everything. There are theories and studies, but not concrete evidence for a lot of things. While the big bang is almost a certainty, it's still technically a theory.

Nothingness after death seems to human, if that makes sense. (Following statements is all my opinion!) Just like how heaven and hell seems too human and orderly to me, I feel like that with nothingness as well. Everything in the universe is endlessly complicated, no way death can be so simple.

In conclusion, I feel like nothingness after death is often seen as the "intelligent" option even though we have 0 evidence. It's best not to think about death, as we will never ever truly know.

(OPINION)

You shouldn't fear death because it happens to everyone.
*laughs in
Being shot in the face by an intruder.
Drowning in the ocean.
Unable to breathe (emphysema or heart failure).
Trapped in a car that falls off a bridge.
Crushed by a stampeding mob.
Radiation poisoning (usually, but not always, from a terrorist bomb; radon poisoning is no good, either).
Bitten by a rabid animal (foaming at the mouth, convulsing uncontrollably, etc.).
Anaphylaxis from a bee bite or from drugs (a variation on not being able to breathe).
Poisoning from contaminated vegetables or chicken that has not been handled properly.
Alzheimer’s disease (not being able to remember family, not being able to talk).
Brain tumors (uncontrollable headaches, convulsions, operations, pain).
AIDS (slow wasting away, an embarrassing disease, prolonged course).
Multiple sclerosis (losing bodily functions, one after the other, crippled, blind, prolonged course).
Diabetes (amputations, blindness, untreatable ulcers, kidney dialysis).
A complication of surgery (going to sleep and expecting to wake up, but not waking up).
A pointless, sudden accident, such as getting hit by a bus that jumps the curb.
Gastrointestinal diseases that cause incontinence, or other such deaths that are undignified and embarrassing

I was there through all of it. Not in the way I am now, not aware of it, but I was. There’s something beautiful about that to me. And what’s even crazier is, I always will be. People who don’t believe in the afterlife describe death as “nothingness”, because we won’t have a brain to process things in the way we do now. But if there isn’t an afterlife (which I don’t know for sure), then I wouldn’t say death is nothingness, but rather becoming everything. It’s an everythingness. If you’ve ever felt moved watching a sunset or observing the universe, take comfort in knowing someday you will be there, part of it.

But, that’s not to devalue life. Like he said, incredible that we exist the way we do right now, able to process and create meaning. I think it was Bill Nye who said something along the lines of “we are the universe becoming aware of itself” (idk the exact quote). And that’s so, so amazing.

We cannot reason with death or the infinite universe but we can convince ourselves we have! That is the beautiful complexity of being human.
Our brain cannot distinguish visualization and reality as the same sections of the brain are activated even the optic nerve with close eyes! Amazing structure our brain is 🙂.

One thing we can look forward to higher levels than normal of DMT that are secreted into the blood stream upon death, blood work in post mortem has shown this.
For those who don't know DMT (dimethyltryptamine) is a compound responsible for hallucination and transcendental like states in the brain and is secreted in minor doses during stages of sleep most closely related to dream phases.
Scientists and neurologists have hypothesized that upon death our body knows what's happening and is trying to limit the detrimental conscious effects of us knowing by altering our consciousness. This means that we may be subject to a dream like state upon cardiac arrest and since the brain has zero reference of time in a dream and how long it lasts we may be in this states for "eternity". Of course we aren't BUT the brain doesn't know that 😉. Remember the brain cannot discern internal visualization from reality.

I'm not scared of death. I just resent it. There is too much to experience in this short lifetime & I've lost a lot of time already due to my own mistakes or the things that have happened to me.  What's worse, I feel sort of trapped into just surviving rather than enjoying life as I see myself getting older and older, with no family and few friends, and no real hope that my life can ever be as good as it once was.  Another day, and it's gone.  Another day, and it's gone.  Another day, and it's gone.  It's a pointless, lonely slog toward death.  I've spent the last full month just trying to resolve computer problems I've been having, and occasionally checking in on the coronavirus.  Even then I play videos in the background while I do other things, rather than just sitting and watching them.  And I get no closer to having a girlfriend, traveling, living in intentional community, having meaningful work, volunteering with wildlife organizations, or leaving any kind of lasting legacy.  Get back to me when you guys are 58 and let me know how you feel about death.  If I was offered the chance to live forever, hell yes, I'd take it!!

Here’s why you’re wrong.
Just because something is natural, this doesn’t make it good. This is a clear example of the naturalistic fallacy. Essentially, all of this interest in the science of how death works doesn’t give any influence on the positivity or negativity of death, it’s just explaining why it’s there.

Many people want to die, but I don’t, and let me explain why.

Death doesn’t give life meaning. Misery isn’t required for happiness to have meaning, happiness is meaning itself. If people didn’t die and I started a murderous rampage to ‘give life meaning,’ and once everyone was dead I killed myself to give my own life meaning, I’d be an outright monster.

If death were gone, we wouldn’t reconstruct a reaper to give life meaning.

And yes, death IS a part of life, but so was cholera before we developed proper ways of preventing the mix between water and disease.

If death were a person, he’d kill millions daily, which is an irredeemable act in and of itself, but if death is ay okay and is a good thing, this embodiment of death is a good person. Do you see how insane that is? Even if death isn’t a person, simply entertaining the idea that it is would mean that the slaughter of what will eventually be every person is a good thing.

If you had the ability to cure cancer, would you?

You’ll say yes if you have any sense of morals.

If you had the ability to stop murder and manslaughter, would you?

Again, you’ll say yes if you have any sense of morality.

I could keep going, but just about everything that causes death is bad. If you give an example of something that was good and causes death I could simply say it can be improved.

For example, people who do dangerous things that could kill them, but those things are necessary for society.

If you had the power to improve the work done in those fields so that it doesn’t kill anyone, would you?

You’ll say yes if you have basic morals.

So, if every cause of death is drastically immoral, not to solve, then I ask you a new question.

If you could cure death, would you?

You might say old age, but people don’t die of old age. People die due to the effects of aging.

If you believe death is a good thing, you’ll say yes to this question, but then you’re leaving some cause of death open, DELIBERATELY. In other words, you’re allowing suicide, or cancer, or murder ect. To exist.

If you had the choice to cure death and didn’t, you’re a monster of the likes the world has never seen... You had the ability to prevent millennium of years and suffering and you didn’t.

So, you’re reasons are wrong because;

1. Humans are meaning making machines, but portraying death is developing upon that idea. I never said meaning doesn’t exist with death in the picture, but it also exists with death out of the picture.

In other words, yes, live a meaningful life, but don’t delude yourself into believing in horrible things being good in the process. Live a meaningful life while looking at its imperfections, one being death.

2. We are insignificant in the long run. Just because I have more of a cell that I couldn’t see if it were put in front of me doesn’t than burning balls of plasma that can make planets, which can make life, that doesn’t make me feel significant. You can list off numbers and intelligence as much as you want, but I can still say, without a doubt, that even if I made more of a difference than any other person in the world, my name will still be forgotten.

3. This doesn’t make life great. Life is inherently great, death or no death. CGP grey made an amazing video on this a while back, I highly recommend it.

4. This argument is a non-sequitur even when we consider the full argument, but I think your conclusion is correct. This is still true without death, though. An infinite life is still one with infinite fun to be had. It’s still one which can be lived to the fullest.

I'm glad you went to the ought/is distinction, but there's still some scientificism in this video.

Take 3:40 for example. You can't describe your whole life in physical terms because some properties are irreducible to physical properties. Take any emotion, for example. We can describe the exact physical state
- neurons firing and chemical reactions burning in the brain - that always accompany a certain emotion.

But they aren't the same. Just as the color "red" that appears in your vision isn't the luminous wavelength that causes it. Causality is a strict relationship, but it isn't identity, because one of those things is objective and the other is subjective, that is, it is for a subject. We can't think of strictly subjective things in objective terms.

This is what David Chalmers', a contemporary philosopher of the mind, terms the "one way paradox": properties of consciousness emerge from physical elements, but is altogether different from them. Note: this isn't a claim for the existence of the soul, that is, consciousness distinct from manner. It's a more nuanced view.

What I think people fear the most is not death itself, but rather the act of dying. We worry it will be painful, both physically and mentally. We fear that there may be nothing afterwards, and that we will forever be denied the gift of life itself. On one level we can understand that there was a time in history where "we" didn't exist, but it more difficult to comprehend that a time will come where "we" no longer exist. Within a generation or two, we will be forgotten and will be little more than a name or perhaps some family photos. Life is short and transient people, tomorrow is promised to no one. Try to live life to the fullest and experience all that you can.

I think many come here with the same fear of not death itself, but what’s after. Here’s my take fwiw: we’re all energy at the end of the day, and by extension so is our consciousness. When we’re gone, our energy is released back into the universe, since energy can’t be created or destroyed, just converted. All the atoms and subatomic particles that made us us goes back to the universe too. Whether you’re buried in the ground or cremated, it all goes back. While statistically the chances of it are dang near zero, it’s not completely zero, so whose to say that whatever energy and combination of subatomic particles that helped make us exist in the first place, all actions that are basically one giant butterfly effect that is the coming together of us before we were born can’t come back together as a sentient being again, and we come back as, well, ourself? Maybe not 100% ourself, but at the very least the thing that made our consciousness, the thing that gave us our personalities, our memories, etc. While I take many stories of alleged reincarnation with a grain of salt, I also don’t completely 100% discredit them. It could be the same reason why we experience deja vu: somewhere in our consciousness, some subatomic particles may vibrate in such a way that gives us the tiniest glimpse into a previous life, that we’ve done something like this before, but you just can’t put your finger on it. Who knows, maybe some people get lucky and can actually remember their past life, same reason why some organ donor recipients take on the personalities of whoever’s organ they got, since to some extent you’re absorbing some of their being. It could be the day after you die, it could be in a billion years, it could take several big bangs for it to happen, who knows. Either way, to quote a Kurzgesagt video: just blink or snap your fingers. That’s how longer forever was for you before you were born. After your gone, that’s how long forever will be too, up until those energies and particles come together again.

What is a god but an idea to express a concept beyond our human understanding? Imagine if time was a pinpoint- everything that is, has been, or ever will be is all occurring in a single moment- and you can experience all of this at a glance. You have no frame of reference to process this, as you live in a 4 dimensional world where space time is linear. Viewed from more complex dimensions, all of time would be simply a point. You could watch eternity and be omniscient to humans if you could return to this dimension. Would that make you a God? If our spirits move as pure energy to these higher dimensions, each of us is then a God. Or we are all part of one God who created this dimension from the stuff of its own substance, and that stuff will be reused, perhaps in a sentient being, perhaps not. But maybe, just maybe- we are all Gods in training. When our spirits are freed to become omniscient, we each create our own universe, in whichever dimension we prefer. Either way, human ego could not survive, it’s simply not sufficient. So you might be immortal, but you won’t be you anymore anyway anyhow. That’s the finality of death. And it’s a good thing. Ego is the source of all evil.

Death is not something that we can really intellectualize or be objective about. We can see the other how death is happening, but we cannot tell what is subjectively going on within at the moment of death. I think that is the major fear we have, especially if you are a control freaks... what is happening to us at the end of life?

The brain has activity at the end of life as we give our last breath. What is that activity in our consciousness, we may never know. Also, at the moment of death, it is said the pineal gland releases a ton of DMT (known as the spirit molecule). Purpose or reason? We can't know.

Buddha once said that when you go to sleep, sleep so deeply as if you will never wake up again. Each night be prepared to die fully, for we may never know when death will come to us.

May we all understand our own mortality and be at peace with it.
