Pero no morimos, es como dicen diferentes religiones y creencias (varias de ellas, las que se cuestionaron al respecto e intentaron dar respuesta) en ellas dice que morimos y volvemos a nacer, algo así como reencarnaciones después de un tiempo. Eso también puede ser comprobado con experiencias de enfermeras, personas que trabajan en la morgue o los que realizan autopsias, los gestos de las personas y como se relajan cuando se les habla, o los que sienten "otras presencias". Según mi modo de ver, el cuerpo físico muere pero la energía que le dió "vida" a ese cuerpo no se pierde sólo se transforma, esa información se "codifica" se "encripta" y en la realidad que deja esa "energía-alma" no tenemos el "hardware" para decodificarla de nuevo. Supongo que los "fantasmas" son como una línea de unión entre la codificación y la realidad que no se quiere dejar o un fragmento que quedó atrás (sea por la razón que sea) Ahora, cuando la persona antes de morir prometió buscar a alguien o tuvo un sentimiento muy fuerte por alguien es que luego (en la siguiente vida del círculo) busca a esa energía. Esto podría justificar recuerdos de vidas pasadas o lugares conocidos que nunca se visitó. Por otro lado si se busca venganza o si la muerte se dió de  forma violenta, justificaría el karma que habría que superar. Todo esto estaría justificado entendiendo el concepto de "ser humano", como una "parte microscópica de dios", sea cual sea la religión o creencia que se profese. Y a Dios como la energía positiva más grande de todas, la que generó el big bang, la vida misma. Según esto, el ser humano seguiría el curso de la vida, el flujo del universo en expansión hasta volver a ingresar a un agujero negro. Como la energía vital es positiva se espera que con estas "reencarnaciones" el ser humano viva otra vez en otro segmento de un multiverso hasta encontrar y reunirse con todos sus seres queridos, hasta que sea felíz junto con ellos. I am convinced there is life after death for one reason: Jesus Christ died and was placed in a tomb–and two days later came back to life.

Think about it a moment: What would it take to prove to us that there is life after death? The answer is clear: Someone would have to die, and then come back to life again. It wouldn’t be enough for them to have a so-called “near-death” experience; their death would have to be real. And it wouldn’t be enough for only one or two people to see them; it would require many witnesses.

But has this ever happened? Yes–when Jesus Christ rose from the grave! His death was real; hard-bitten Roman guards made sure He was dead before they took Him down from the cross. And His resurrection was real also, because hundreds saw Him during the next forty days. Paul, writing over 25 years later, noted that “he appeared to more than five hundred of the brothers at the same time, most of whom are still living” (1 Corinthians 15:6).

How could this happen? It happened because Jesus Christ was not just another man. He was God’s only Son, sent from heaven to save us from our sins. Only He could say, “I am the resurrection and the life. … Whoever lives and believes in me will never die” (John 11:25-26). This can be your hope, by giving your life to Christ today.

An interesting paradox is that fear is usually only born out of that which has left an impression of pain or suffering on the individual for whom the fear exists. What this means is that fear of death is an irrational fear because you only experience dying once and death only occurs one time, there is no impression from which to base nervous tension and fear based anxiety. It is quite the conundrum, if you ask me. I think people who fear death the most are those who are living life the least, it is relative to how much you embrace that which is your current existence. The more you overthink and overprocess, the more you welcome the catastrophizing delusions concerning what it'll be like. I think people rather fear the process that is dying, and not so much death itself. Because in death there is no pain and suffering from which to be effected and no fear to cling to.

I absolutely love your videos. I respect, & very much appreciate the knowledge and insight that you share to the public. Your narrating & illustration has been a staple; it works very well to make many  advanced and/or interesting concepts easier to conceptualize in addition to being fun to watch. Your mind is beautiful with your method and theories to reflect such, not to mention your scientifically based “dry humor” literally has me dying laughing out loud while watching.  Now, I have been a logical, scientific person for much of my life. In fact, the introduction to this video was very cute and also proved nostalgic to me. I first conceptualized death however at a much younger age, maybe eight or nine years old. My love for science came consuming my mind in constant process & methodological thought. Learning to distract my thoughts from the anxiety inducing thought of death came soon after. Seeing this video in my suggestions made me very excited to grasp a hint of your stunning thought process yet again & perhaps finally put my mind at ease. I actually thought it would put my mind at ease because you are so based in scientific method followed closely with care and emotion that I didn’t doubt your knowledge pair elegantly with your vast knowledge and comfortable voice  would sooth me into a state of relaxation. I am very upset that it did not. In almost a way similar to how any politician would answer how they were going to solve poverty or unemployment, you beat around the bush so well. The answer to why not to fear death you did provide & I lie distressed that even your thoughts can sooth your mind yet have not taken as such to mine. I know and understand all you have said within this video, I’ve known it for some time. Yet humans thrive off of hurting one an other, more & more people fall into this and cause destruction to the earth, each other and themselves. Working to live longer & keeping everyone happy is almost impossible. Greed is a learned quality & as far from a virtue that you can possibly go, yet it is infecting the minds of most of the public due to our society & political systems. If I don’t see an end to the human race (excluding the very wealthy) in my life time, i believe it will soon follow after. My consciousness that is held within this vessel I use as a tool called my human body still fears where it can collect & remain in the motion of thought after its vessel begins to rot & fade through as all biological things do. The idea of not doing anything is unproductive & not being able to contemplate how to improve the lives of alll & myself kills me & still is restlessly uneasy about the thought of death. Ironically speaking of course. Distraction will remain the answer.

I am not afraid of death. I know that death is going to happen, so from a logical standpoint, why should I be afraid of something I can't prevent? My real fear is dying before I get a chance to make a difference in the world. But really, I'm not too scared about that either, because as long as I'm alive, I can choose to do things that can make a positive impact on the world. I'm religious, too, so I believe in the afterlife. But before anyone criticizes that, think about this: there are plenty of things that people believe and hope will happen, whether pertaining to this life or what happens after. It's human nature to have things that they hope for. This allows humans to develop trust. We trust that something good will happen. We trust that our relationships will last a lifetime or longer. We trust others to keep their promises. And sometimes that trust is broken. Sometimes things don't go as you originally planned or hoped. But that doesn't mean you shouldn't trust in anything good. We humans are social creatures. We can't function properly without being able to rely on others for support when we need it. We can't do everything alone. So if it turns out that there is no afterlife, that there is no higher power, and that there is nothing after death, why should it matter what I believe? If it helps me to find meaning in life, and helps me to look past my own problems to help others, then even if the belief is false, my life will have been worth living either way.

Sure you can't live forever but prolonging that eventuality until the heat death sounds like a good goal. Who doesn't want to watch the cosmos unfold throughout the eons? There are no meanings anywhere. You make your own purpose, so mine is to prevent death longer than humanly possible.

I have to say, I have been greatly disappointed by this video. First, because it spoke very little about why one shouldn't fear death; second, because the reasoning was mostly just "lol, you're gonna die anyway, and be forgotten...". I have expected something more along the lines of "Optimistic Nihilism" from the Kurzgesagt channel, if you must stick to the "you are going to die" narrative.

However, I am mostly disappointed by this "death acceptivist" approach, which we should not encourage in this day and age. I would recommend two CGP Grey videos for those who do not "subscribe" to this idea: a more paraphrased one is "The Fable of the Dragon-Tyrant", and a more direct, no BS one is "Why Die?". I think those are more encouraging and inspiring.

There is only one way to not be afraid of dying. To explain this I need to start with the bad news...


The bad news is that all mankind has fallen from what we were created to be. When Adam sinned, he represented all of us and we fell with him. This is why we all sin. We don’t honour God as we should, and we sin against our fellow man as well. We do this right from our childhood because the corruption affects every part of us. No one is exempt. We all know our own sin, at least enough of it to know we’re guilty. Our consciences tell us that things are not okay. Death is part of the curse. We were never meant to die.

There was one exception to the cursed line of Adam. Jesus is very special in a bio of ways. He was born of the Holy Spirit, not an earthly father. So he’s God. He existed before creation. The Bible actually calls him the creator. But he’s also a man like any other. Not 50/50 God and man, but completely God and also completely man. He had to be a man so he could be a suitable substitute for sinful man, and he had to be God so he could bear the awful weight of judgment that sin deserves.

So Jesus was tempted by Satan in the wilderness by many temptations. He was hungry because he was fasting. He was in danger from wild animals. He was tired, lacking sleep. Compare Adam, who was tempted while in paradise and still failed. The Bible calls Jesus the second Adam. Where Adam failed, Jesus succeeded. God said he was pleased with his son Jesus. What Adam could have earned if he remained faithful until eating from the tree of life, Jesus actually earned instead. He earned perfect righteousness for his people. That’s why God promises an amazing inheritance to his people. Not because they earned it, but because Jesus earned it for them. Eternal life, endless joy, living in God’s presence, enjoying God’s riches for eternity.

After his righteous life, Jesus gave himself up to be crucified. A horrible way to die, reserved for the worst offenders. Even God said in the OT that someone hanged on a tree was cursed. God poured out his wrath against the sin of his people on Jesus.

2 Corinthians 5:21 He made Him who knew no sin to be sin on our behalf, so that we might become the righteousness of God in Him.

The great exchange. When we cease trying to bribe God with our own efforts and simply trust what Jesus did for us, he legally declares us righteous as though we lived his life. He also legally charges our sin to his account. All we do is believe him. Trust that he will do what he said. So even though I’m a sinner, I’m loved by God like his own Son. The law in the Bible tells me how to live and what God wants, but I can never live it out. I try, to honour him out of thankfulness, but he doesn’t judge me by his law anymore.

Continued...
Unless...

God shows us his wrath against sin by those he doesn’t save. Those who resist his command to trust Jesus and rather bribe God with their own efforts will never be good enough to please a holy God. He’s a perfect judge and requires absolute perfection. If we’re not perfect on our own, and we don’t have a perfect substitute, he will send us to hell until we can pay off the debt. Which will never happen. Sinners in hell go on hating God and increasing their debt. So the punishment is eternal.

Or some simply don’t even try to bribe him with their efforts. They openly hate God and will suffer the same fate. But Jesus says that anyone who comes to him he will never cast out. But we must come on his terms. He is God, after all. Many have deceived themselves thinking they are his, but he says he will say to them “I never knew you”.
That’s the gospel, in a nutshell.
Forgot something. Jesus was raised from the dead because God was showing that Jesus had accomplished his mission. His sacrifice was acceptable to God and needs nothing added. We too will be resurrected in real physical bodies, to live on a re-created earth. God will live with us here on planet earth, but a totally renewed earth without the curse and all that came with it. Unbelievers will have resurrected bodies to experience the wrath of God without being able to escape by death. So when we die, we either go to a place of comfort or torment until the resurrection. Then in our new bodies, we live in an earthly/heavenly paradise or the lake of fire.

God bless everyone who reads this. My prayer is that you open your minds and hearts to this message and receive Jesus as your Saviour and substitute. Praise God for such an incredible gift! ❤️

Y'know, evolution really baffles me sometimes. At the very beginning, we know  that it started from groups of molecules that happened to be able to replicate themselves, whether it was on Earth or another planet. So what really makes me think is how certain features are spontaneously evolved. Consider the eye, more advanced and complex than any camera, yet only the size of a bouncy ball. I know it wasn't evolved on its own, but over time, but how did organisms spontaneously evolve light sensing organs? And really the same for anything else. On top of that, there are some really strange,but very successful stories in evolution. Consider the sawfish,a shark that literally uses a sword to kill/stun its prey! How did that evolved, and what really prompted it? the fish not only had to evolve a long snout, but also had to evolve separate teeth on the snout! Some other really good examples of this would include parrotfish, which blow themselves mucus bubbles to sleep in at night, the goblin shark, which has a big extrusion on its forehead, myriapods, which I wonder what exactly favored that many legs, and so many others. And of course, Us.

Yesterday I found out one of my aunts died. It wasnt one of my closest aunts but it was someone I knew since childhood, going to her house a lot. She was a sweet woman. Good sense of humour, obsessed with Elvis. It's hard for me to grasp that not only did she die... but she died in one of the worst ways imaginable. The person who killed her (not really a person, more like walking garbage) hasn't been caught and brought to justice. She hit by a moron who ran a red light and fled the scene. She lost 80% of her blood and was pretty much comatose for 4 months before they had to pull the plug on her. It's so devastating and her husband died in 2016 so I have a 19 year old cousin without any parents and my heart is so heavy about all this. Most deaths in my family have been from old age/stroke/heart attacks and have been sad but peaceful and relatively quick. This one... however... is like something out of a movie and that's the kind of death that terrifies me. And the worst part is... aside from the cunt who fled the scene and is still out there with blood on his hands... is the fact that this is someone I knew as a LIVING person. Someone with smiles and laughters, with two children and a stepdaughter. Someone who wasnt related by blood but family nonetheless. Someone who I spent vacations with a lot because her birthday is 2 days after my mom's. Her 25 or 26 year old daughter is getting married soon and she sadly wont be there in person. It's just so sad. And how horrible she went. And the death of those I love is harder to swallow than my own. At least I wont be there to mourn my own death. I hope I go as an old man peacefully. Not in my 50s, still relatively young, and gored to death.

Why you SHOULD fear death:

1) It is often accompanied by pain (physical, emotional, etc, by you or your loved ones)

2) It marks the end of the joy of living (pursuit of knowledge, bettering oneself, experiencing the happiness of others, etc)

We want to be brave and pretend like nothing scares us, including the ultimate threat: death. But its inevitability doesn’t make it preferrable, nor in any way a source of joy.

This by no means makes us cowards. Instead, we face that which we fear head on, which is by definition, courage

As CGP Grey once said, "saying death gives meaning to life is like saying sadness gives meaning to happiness. It's just plain stupid. You don't need to be sad to appreciate happiness. Happiness itself has got it's own meaning."

Whenever you're offered happiness, you accept it even if you haven't been sad your entire life. Which proves that you don't really need to be sad to appreciate happiness. And in the same way, you don't need death to give meaning to your life. Even if you become immortal, you'd still want to eat your favorite food, do your favorite stuff, love your favorite person and enjoy your life. It's not like once you know you're immortal, you'd just sit out your whole life in a room. You'd still like to do something that you're good at, you'd still like to earn money. You'd still like to do good for the world (if you're into that sort of thing). Your life already has a meaning. You don't fear death anyway. Not in general. You work hard for stuff even though you know you're gonna eventually die. So yeah, always remember, death doesn't give meaning to your life.

Several years ago, I answered the door to religious recruiters (I have nothing against religion per se, just recruiters of any sort). The man of the couple straight up demanded of me if I "wanted to live forever?". I told him just as straight up "NO". On his asking why not, I mentioned that even though I wasn't quite 50, I had already been in constant pain of varying degrees for at least the last decade due to arthritis; and that I would be content to persevere until about 70. At which age I suspected I would not be as sociable to strangers knocking on my door unless they tied my shoelaces, hooked my bra, cut up my meat, trimmed my nails, poured from the kettle, mashed the potatoes, brushed my kids hair, brushed my teeth, wrote everything down or any other job my own hands can no longer do for me. I then told him I'd be most happy to talk about life and death after I'd had both hands transplanted, as I would then be able to focus on such things that are not immediately practical to my own life. I never saw him again, but his wife and I did have several nice chats over a couple of months. The point to my rant is: there's no point fearing death when you've got a broken-down body and/or mind to look forward to in old age (or not so old age, either).

Well when you really think about it, you are nothing special. You are made up of the most common elements in the universe. There is not a single thing about you is special. You were nothing before you were something. You were dead for billions of years and will be for the next infinity after you die. Life can only possibly exist for 0.000000003% of the universe’s life span. Everything you feel or know is a passing grain of sand in a beach that is as long as the sun is wide. Nothing you ever do or think will matter in the grand scheme of things. So why live your life when none of it matters? Well you are lucky to be alive. You have people who care about you. You experience things that really matter to you. And no matter how big the universe is or how meaningless everything really is, there is still one undeniable truth. You will have the great opportunity to find love, in someone or something. You will have the hurtful and disgusting lows to make the highs so much better. Because we, as humans determine how good something is by how bad we have felt. And no matter what there is one undeniable truth, that this life, your life is the only one you will have. So enjoy it

Reasons to fear death:

1. Evolution would probably not work unless we had a survival instinct that makes us fear death. I don't think saying "you shouldn't" changes that. It's like telling a dog not to wag its tail.

2. Death is a process that almost always involves some form of suffering. If I could die instantly, it wouldn't be so bad, but I don't want to die because I don't want to suffer.

3. On top of that, most people believe in is some form of afterlife (which science cannot tell you anything about), and many people worry about that big unknown. Limiting your scope to what science can tell you is like ignoring what could be of even greater importance than life itself.

This is not helping at all, sorry! As someone who tends to think about death more than I'd like, all of these points popped up a long time ago. As a rational humanist, I don't think there is a meaning in either life nor death - we can make one up and believe in it though. Of course my atoms will stay around but how does this help me loosing my consciousness and never (!) being able to recover it? I'll never be able to think or feel anything again or contemplate our universe and our very weird situation once we're born. I think the fact that most people tend to say "I think it's good that life eventually ends" is rather discomforting, to me it means that probably some of those don't really seem to have a full grasp on what it actually means to die. I think videos like this just try to calm people down, but in the end, it just sucks to know that eventually, sooner or later, you're going to stop existing forever. And there's nothing you can do about it. And remember how fast the last 10 years since 2009 seemed to have past? Yeah, time flies. Bummer.

The most terrifying aspect of death is that, not one single person knows exactly what happens to our consciousness when we die. It could just cease to exist, as it was before we were born. Just try to imagine ‘nothing’. Non-existence. Not even empty blackness or complete silence; purely the absence of anything at all. Our years of memories, experiences, thoughts, etc. could ultimately fade away into eternal unconsciousness, never another thought or feeling or experience.


If however, our consciousness does somehow transfer from the brain upon death, there are an infinite number of possibilities of what we could experience.


We could transfer to some otherworldly plane; anything from the most horrendous hellscape to the most euphoric paradise. We could exist in an astral expanse of pure energy among the cosmos, or in a state of being that is completely incomprehensible to human understanding. It could be eternal or it could be cyclical, continuously reincarnating or reliving different lives. When we "die", we might just find ourselves waking up from the simulation/dream and go on to live our 'real lives' in some other part of the universe.


Because there's no demonstrable evidence of what actually happens, it could literally be ANYTHING, which is mind-boggling to try to comprehend. And because it's coming for us all and we have to face it, whether we are ready or not, it can be a terrifying prospect.

This is all nice and wonderful but it doesn't exactly address the question... I think the actually good reason to no fear death is to recognize that you won't be aware of it. Like, you can be aware of dying and that sucks for most people, but after that there's just nothing. I have a suspicion most people who don't believe in afterlife imagine there being blackness or nothingness after death but that's not the case. At the moment of death, you cease to exist. There won't be awareness, and there won't be a you to be scared of it. Imagine it like this: are you afraid of 1761? You probably aren't, but you didn't exist back then. So you've got All particles that exist, right? These particles are divided into two subcategories, fermions and bosons. Fermions have a half integral quantum spin (like 1/2, 3/2, 7/2) and are matter, while bosons have a whole quantum spin (like 1,2,3,4) and are messanger particles of forces, such as gravity and electromagnetism. There are two types of fermions, leptons and quarks. Quarks have a fractional electric charge (2/3 or -1/3) while Leptons have a whole electric charge (like 1).


Particles
/ \
/ \
Fermions Bosons
- half integral quantum spin - whole quantum spin
- matter - messanger force particles
- Examples : Strange quark, - Examples: Photon, Gluon, W boson, etc.
electron, muon, neutrino - do not have to have a mass
/ \
/ \
/ \
Leptons Quarks
- whole electric charge - fractional electric charge (either 2/3 or -1/3)
- Examples : Electron, Neutrino, Tau, - Examples : Top quark, Strange Quark, Up quark,
Muon, Muon-neutrino, etc. Charm quark, Down quark, Bottom quark.




In fermions, there are three families that divide them, each containing 2 leptons, one an electron-type, one a neutrino, and two quarks, one with a charge of -1/3, one with a charge of 2/3. Each electron-type lepton is, well, the same as an electron, but heavier as each family progresses, Electron being the lightest, Tau being the heaviest. (Top quark in the Tau family is a very heavy particle)


Electron | Muon | Tau |
Up quark (charge=2/3) | Charm quark (charge = 2/3) | Top quark (charge = 2/3) |
Down quark (-1/3) | Strange quark (-1/3) | Bottom quark (-1/3) |
Electron-neutrino | Muon-Neutrino | Tau-neutrino |


For each of the main forces (written in order from weakest to strongest) Gravity, Weak Nuclear Force, Electromagnetism, Strong Nuclear Force, there are bosons that transmit them. (Though gravity's is hypothetical/theoretical)


Electromagnetism : Photon (charge = 0)
Strong Nuclear Force: Gluon (charge = 0)
Weak Nuclear Force : W+ Boson (charge = +1), W- boson (charge = -1), Z boson (charge = 0)
Gravity : THEORETICAL Graviton (charge = 0)


Thats been basics on knowing your particles!




note: Particles with an electric charge of zero are their own antiparticles/matter
